text: When I'm frustrated I exercise or run an errand. When I'm bored I read or study. When I'm sad I try to justify that I can't control the actions of others and staying like this won't help. If I begin to feel sorry for myself I think ' I'm the only one who can solve this so why burden others' if I'm angry with someone I try to dismiss argumental thoughts and put it down to that they are and will always be like this until they themselves decide to change their actions, I cannot do it for themÔªø

text: Saying meditation is just trying to focus on one thing, is pretty misleading. I realize that meditation has made its way into the western world because of the benefits in regards to productivity. But meditation is not really focusing one thing, or emptying your mind. author: Nick g

text:
Definitely *FITNESS*, specifically running. Running is my "keystone" habit.  I also read and meditate but running is the one habit that makes all the difference and makes everything else that I do less of a burden.  If I only read or only meditate I just don't get the same benefits, but if I run then this permeates in very positive ways through the rest of my life.  The result is that meditation and reading seem easier and more natural to do.  For me meditation/reading do not make me more motivated to run.  In any case I am not knocking meditation or reading.  Added in with the running meditation and reading definitely make me much more emotionally strong.  

There have been a couple of times where I have injured myself as a runner so I have to be careful in the future to maintain strength and flexibility.  In the past I've only focused on running but this time around I'm including the strength training and stretching to support the running.  It will become even more important as I get older.  This is not a 21 day habit, nor something I would just do for a year and then just stop.  It really is a habit that needs to be maintained throughout your life.   It sounds painful and overwhelming in the beginning to think that far ahead since we are so used to getting our fix without having to wait but over time you complain less and less about it and really start to see how your whole mindset shifts and you realize the putting in the effort is very much worth it.  You do get the feeling that brighter days are ahead and that even if dark days do come you'll have the strength to deal with them.Ôªø

text:
I‚Äôve actually recently started meditating. I‚Äôd tried it a few times, but I just couldn‚Äôt get into it. I think the reason I had more success with it in these last couple of weeks is because I realized one of the causes of my depression is running away from my problems via distraction. I couldn‚Äôt remember the last time I just sat down without doing anything but relaxing. I‚Äôm always staring at my phone and watching videos, posting on Facebook, just a bunch of stuff.

What I do, for those of you trying to start meditation, is I put some relaxing music on and set a timer on my phone. Start out with less time, probably ten minutes or so, and just sit with your eyes closed and relax. DO NOT CHECK THE TIMER!! You know how long you set it for, don‚Äôt worry about how much time is left.
I just did my first 30 minute meditation, and it helps so much. I think within the next week, I‚Äôd like to try to take up reading a book.Ôªø

text:
Meditation everyday with Insight Timer, Workout in the Gym or at Home with Home Workout, Read everyday

72 Books later, thousands of hours of meditation and hundreds if not thousands of hours of constant working out 5 times a day and pushing the bar every time I am mentally so much stronger and physically then i have ever been, my cynical mindset of the world vanished and I see things from a more objective truth level. I also feel better within my brain , I am trying to work out a new diet now to widen those effects and I've already put habits in place like rituals, affirmations and brain excercises. It does help you become a better person, 40% is doing it, 60% is staying consistent.Ôªø

text: I believe that everyone has different ways of meditating. You can achieve that stillness in different ways, doing different things. As long as you feel refreshed and you set aside time to do so. author: stijn hemelaer

text:
I'll tell you a trick. Start with reading. If you started reading, read on fitness/diets/nutrition or meditation/yoga (Whispers: Yoga is 2 in 1). Once you pick up the habit, you will now have some knowledge or motivation to meditate or exercise. Starting the next one would be easy. You'll be picking 2 habits at once. One result that's likely to happen is you finish reading to apply. HENCE, doing two of these habits at once ;)

Another thing that would make your life great is waking up 2 hours earlier. In these 2 hours you can do all of the 3 habits. Say you'd read 25 pages, meditate for 15 min and exercise for 20 min with 10 warm up. You will feel productive and great to have a great start of the day ;)
Waking up early is the mother habits, if you mastered it your life will tremendously change.  
But for starter, try the first trick for a week or two, then try waking up early to read alone. Once you pick up reading, add meditation and fitness to the early routine. Trust me, your life will change. Be smart ;)Ôªø

Purely financial perspective buying a pre-owned car gives the greatest freedom, both financially and with use.Ôªø

text:
I've heard of and can agree to the renting of a home vs buying it, as the math can work out pretty well if you know what your plan is, but leasing a car sounds bit out of place if you don't have an aim of keeping up with the times. I personally go for cheaper and older models though. I would need to see the math on it I guess, as I only paid 1500 for an 10-12 year old car that works just fine. Any problems I have I end up using it to practice mechanic skills because I know I can trash it and buy a new one in two weeks if push comes to shove.

I'm going to try for the meditation habit. I believe it would be the central habit that I need to really push me into doing what I intend on accomplishing. It also aligns with my weaknesses as a fleshed out person, as my spiritual and inner peace are by far my weakest pillars. And since meditation aligns with my spiritual needs, I believe it provide the largest impact on my life of the options set before me in this video.

Thanks for the video man!Ôªø

text:
over the past year, I have managed to adopt all 3 of these habits, at least 5 days a week. The most important one is meditation. The quiet time and zero distractions re-centers your mind and re-aligns you of your true goals and intentions, while simultaneously strengthening your focus and your ability to resist falling into lower conciousness and slipping up and getting lazy on your habits. 
i'm currently working on keeping my space well organised, and have been flawless for 16 days. in a few weeks when I have this handled, I will start a new habit, and I have no doubt I will succeed. I feel unstoppable. Every time I meditate, I am reminded of all that I want to achieve, and following through on my promises to myself brings me a sense of achievement. I really think this is my year. Thanks Improvement pill.Ôªø

author: Ferhat Demir

text: Hokum... I can read an entire book in one sitting and I never get angry (because I have my emotions completely under control thanks to my understanding of stoicism). I didn't achieve this focus because of meditation but rather because of my calling. I realized what my ideal self would look like and started to aspire to it. I've read well over a thousand books by now (which is not that impressive once you realize that I read about 100 books each year) and if there's one thing that I can tell you it's that philosophical literature has had the biggest impact on my world view. Those are the real gems.... things that can't just be taught in courses. People have to actually develop themselves to the point where they are willing to do work in order to obtain knowledge. Watching a video is the easiest thing in the world. It's akin to junk food. Reading a book on the other hand is an ergodic activity. One has to wrap his mind around concepts and create mental images of their own instead of watching another persons animations. But then again.... most of you people will never understand what I'm trying to convey here. You're not ready yet.Ôªø

author: zsrandomvidz

text: Leasing a car is a bad idea for many reasons. The first reason is at the end of the lease you have nothing to show for all the money that you spent. You either must turn the car into the dealer (where they try to convince you to trade up to a new lease) or you must purchase the car at the end of the lease. There are also hidden fees associated with leasing a car. Often the mileage limits are difficult to stay under, and you may find yourself paying over mileage charges at the end of your lease. Leasing is similar to renting a home, you are constantly paying money and in the end you have nothing to show for it.Ôªø
author: Ken W

text: What do you have when you are done owning a car? An old junk car. It all depends on your individual needs. For most people, leasing probably makes more sense. If you have special driving needs, or an urge to customize your car, you should buy.Ôªø

author: Colton Breving

text:
@christopher, others,

You sound foolish saying leasing is a foolish idea. Did you work the math out or just guessing? If you normally buy a brand new car, then leasing makes more sense.

The lower monthly lease payment compared to a loan payment saves more money than buying new, paying it off, selling and buying new again. You also don't have to worry about repairs.

Buying used is often less expensive than both options assuming you can maintain a car. 

If you buy new and keep forever then you could save money buying used then keeping forever. Maybe you prefer being the only owner and can't maintain the car. Maybe you should look at leasing.

It depends on your car buying/maintaining habits. Queue request @improvement pill for best car habits.Ôªø
author: Natemesis

text: Dealerships make more money when you lease. This is why they push it.Ôªø
author: Yvie Sunshine

text:
There's actually huge benefits to leasing a car, and renting a home/apartment. Not everyone has the same needs and habits as you do. Leasing a car works perfectly for those who want, and can afford, to drive the newest cars. See, for me leasing a car would be perfect if I didn't like to drive long distances multiple times a year. If all I did was commute to work day in and day out, then there would be no reason not to lease a car.
Also, owning a home is a stupid idea FOR ME because it goes against my current goal of living free and not being tied down to anything. At least, not yet. When I'm older and ready to settle down, I will definitely buy a home to live in. For now, the only properties I'll be buying are ones I intend to rent out.Ôªø
author: Damian Rivas

text: Ken W I seriously can't believe he used "lease a car instead of buying" as a foundation of learning money management. When you buy a car, ITS YOURS. THAT IS YOUR LEGAL PROPERTY. A lease is essentially renting a car for two years with extreme restrictions. That, combined with the offhand comment that history is useless in every day life (when it has literally shaped our present and will continue to shape our future, and presents outliers for what's to come) makes me question the rest of this advice. This all just seems very elementary and poorly presented.Ôªø
author: Andy Dietrich

text: Andy Dietrich the comments about school not being useful are indeed the worst part of the video: clearly most people in this thread would benefit from a couple more calculus lessons to understand why leasing a car can be (and often is) better than buying it. What is the financial value of something being "your own legal property"? Zero. You have to look at this from a financial point of view. Leasing a car is usually less expensive than buying new then reselling every x years. Just like renting a place to live can be more financially beneficial than buying one.Ôªø
author: Yann Larriau

text:
Ken W You can adjust as the mileage limit at the end of the lease. I don‚Äòt understand why they allow that, but I had such a situation a few weeks ago.
Also, you can lease a car for 3 years, return it and lease the next car, a newer model for 3 years. I prefer having the newest model over an old, ugly pile of junk any day of the week.
I think there is hardly anyone who doesn‚Äòt want another car or the newer model of his current car after 3-4 years of owning it.Ôªø
author: TDFXX

text: Yann Larriau First of all, calculus has nothing to do with finances, solvency, and the accompanying break even analysis one would conduct to decide if leasing or purchasing would be better for a particular situation - so your false equivalency already gives me a negative impression of your critical thinking skills. Owning a car, and having it as "legal property" means you control the title, and once it's paid off it's paid off. It's capital. The second you lease a car, all it's doing is depreciating. I personally don't know anyone that does or would "buy a car every few years". I have a car from 1981 that is perfectly operational - so that's a moot point. Owning a car gives you capital whereas continuously leasing is just a liability. If your cash flow changes due to extraneous situations, that lease will be a further burden just for having means of transposition. I made my first six figures at 24 but what do I know.Ôªø

text:
I am lactose and fructose intolerant for five years now. Four years and 11 months of it I haven't paid attention to that and the last two years were just horrible. I had headache and I had no energy for anything. Whenever I came home from school (about 2-3pm) I ate something and right after that i fell asleep because as I said I had no energy for doing anything. I had also problems by sleeping at night but I anyways slept about six hours at night plus three hours when I came home after school. So I slept so much but I was anyways tired and sleepy all the day. One week ago I started becoming more healthy and to not eat any lactose products or any fructose products and if you believe or not I feel so much better and I'm not tired anymore just by paying attention to my diet. I don't sleep in the afternoon anymore and also when I have only six hours of sleep. Also I feel so happy, healthy, fit and energised for the day. Not to forget: I am more concentrated on things like when I study or even talk to someone. And I also started to work out a bit like jogging ;)

Btw I'm sorry if there are any mistakes I actually don't speak englishüò¨Ôªø

author: carter samuel

text:
Spot on with Meditation!!!!  

Learning about Vipassana taught me the true use of meditation.

Been "reading", watching videos and learning about meditation for years, then occasionally do a 5min to 10min actual sit down.......

.....but after doing it daily (20mins thrice per day), wow, what a change in 1 single week of doing this compared to years of intellectually understanding it. 

It's funny how it's become my "go to" thing when I feel down. I no longer crave to change the external situation to feel better, I go sit for a while (20mins) in my angry or anxious state, get into that space, start feeling great, then go change the external event with a positive outlook. 

It is so difficult to make it a daily practice as it feels like you wasting time that could be used to change your situation, but once you into it you will understand - it kinda feels like you have more time and don't have that rush mentality and things still get done on time and in better spirits.Ôªø

author: Ich nehme einen McChicken

text:
Your example shows the biggest missing piece in your argument: mimetic desire. The reason the person quit smoking was not self motivation, but external motivation. The most important habit is surrounding myself with people who already do what I want to be doing. Because humans are mimetic creatures / social learners we copy the habits of our surroundings. This makes it much easier to adopt new or change old habits. 

It's why your example suddenly was into fitness and diet, it's also why fat people have fat friends. Reading works exactly that way. It exposes me / my brain to behaviors that can be mimicked. Same goes for video by the way. I can also listen to podcasts. As long as I am paying attention the medium doesn't matter too much.

Fitness is the same thing. Nobody eats healthy because they do fitness. They eat healthy because other people, who do fitness, eat healthy.Ôªø

author: Vitor Diogo

text: Fiction is technically entertainment. Which is great as a writer! But for someone who isn't trying to write a book, perhaps non-fiction would give you better results. Read about subjects that interest you, that you feel you need to know, and that challenge you in some way. Always be mindful when reading for the best results. If you do stick to fiction then I suggest reading consecutively harder to read books with higher levels of language so you at least get wordier :p Picking up writing as a hobby would justify it greatly though. I'm a writer and a game designer, so I read and play games all the time. But I read and play with a critical eye and ensure that I don't merely waste my time with nothing to show for it.Ôªø

text: Hey improvement pill, I have a question. I want to focus on developing the habit in fitness, only problem is that my work schedule can sometimes be all over the place because of the industry I work in, which is on big production films and TV shows. So what I would like to know is how should I go about building this habit? I always thought when it came to working out, that it had to be done at a certain time of day or done at the same time each day and with this hectic schedule that just seems near impossible. I know that I could probably choose one of the other two habits listed but fitness in my opinion is something I need right now due to my very low energy levels & poor eating habits, it's not like I'm obese or anything, hell I'm not even overweight, but im 24 years old and I feel that I should be operating at optimal capacity, but honestly I feel like an old man who barely can get out of bed in the mornings and it sucks. author: Trashbagwilly

text: Tayshaun Haynes hey man don‚Äôt complicate it by worrying about what is the best time, or even what is the best exercise. Just get the habit of being active started, you can refine it later. It is much easier to keep a habit if it‚Äôs at the same time each day because the time of day acts as a reminder or trigger. But you might be able to use something else as a reminder. For me I have only one rule for fitness - I must put my running shoes on after work. That‚Äôs it! It‚Äôs a stupidly simple goal but it works like this - If I don‚Äôt feel active after work I will put my shoes on and then feel like I have completed my goal. I allow myself to not feel bad if I don‚Äôt go work out. That‚Äôs very important. Here‚Äôs the secret though. Nearly every time I put my shoes on, even if I feel terrible, I‚Äôll walk down to the park anyway. Then nearly every time I‚Äôll go for a run or do a calisthenics work out. I‚Äôm pretty much tricking myself into working out and doing something. Even a short half arsed workout is better than not leaving the house. I‚Äôve been doing this for a couple of years now and I have easily made it into a habit that I enjoy. I look and feel great and I‚Äôve found activities that I love and fit well into my lifestyle. Just get moving man, anytime of day :)Ôªø

author: tony Bro

text:
Haces lo siguiente: Cuando termines tu rutina de ejercicios. Entonces vas a casa o si puedes en tu gimnasio o no se , en el parque puede ser si lo haces al aire libre. Entonces en ese estado donde el cuerpo necesita estar relajado y descansar. Aprovechas a sentarte un momento a solas, un lugar donde no te molesten por al menos unos 10 minutos y te sientas comodamente pero con Atencion y Alerta, sin DORMIRTE, pues no se trata de dormirse.
Una vez elijas el lugar y el momento, simplemente te sientas comodamente solo, sin distracciones de ningun tipo, de preferencia cierras los ojos y lo mas probable es que empezara a sonar la famosa "vocecita" en tu cabeza que te empezara a "hablar" de todo (Pasado ,presente y futuro)lo que no has hecho, etc.
Entonces esos pensamientos que surgen, tu los ves , sin criticarlos, sin aferrarte a ellos. Igual como cuando vas al cine y ves una pelicula. Estas sentado viendo un film y solo eres un testigo de lo que acontece en la pantalla. Igual, es lo que pasara cuando estes sentado en silencio y entonces solo permanece como un testigo nada mas. Y asi lo que dure y decidas sentarte. 
Despues de esto, de ver tu propia pelicula ,sin haberla criticado, sin poner nigun comentario, etc. entonces sigues tu vida normal.
Poco a poco si lo practicas, esta interiorizacion te ira dando mas y mas respuestas sobre preguntas que siempre has tenido.

Los libros, pues lee los temas que te atraigan. Dedica un dia a visitar una buena libreria y dedica un tiempo adecuado sin prisa y tension a ver las estanterias y te puedo asegurar que al leer algunos, encontraras el adecuado, y esto sucede asi porque de manera muy extra√±a, suele ser "El libro quien llama al lector".Ôªø

author: Marcin Widz

text:
I agree with each of these habits and incorporate all 3. I would like to offer an alternative look at grade school. Any system can be improved; and the system through which we educate our students can be improved. At the same time, the things we learn in school provide a basic foundation upon which all the other knowledge we acquire later in life is built. The lessons we learn later in life needs something to stand on when it enters our brains and that "formal" education provides that.

Perhaps we should not sell students on the idea that their education is complete once they finish school. There's no way any of us can know with absolute certainty all that we'll need to know later in life.

If there was a tweak I'd make to the education system, it would be placing an emphasis on how to learn. In this way, when students leave the "formal" education system, they have an understanding that they are now taking over the responsibility of educating themselves because there's no way that any school system could ever teach all that needs to be known. 

Students need to really grasp that what they're receiving is a foundation that will assist in the assimilation of everything else they'll learn over their lifetime.Ôªø

author: Kaedence Jairl

text:
Some guy I read one novel per week and workout 3-4 times per week, lifting and cardio. I also meditate every other day for at least 15 min. While all these habits  may be conducive to a healthy, happy, lifestyle, there is one particular weakness that will throw all of these off. That weakness is poor sleep. If your not receiving the proper sleep your body needs daily, then you can train your brain (so to speak) all you want, but will continue to fall short of your goals until you give your body adequate rest. 

Not a professional health specialist, but personally this seems to be the key for my lifestyle.Ôªø

text: Danny Juarez yes you can look up a video if you want, however for me personally all the videos on YouTube are subject to different opinions on how to meditate. The key is to pick the correct way that feels most natural to you. I suggest looking up meditative music on YouTube, because this will help you focus. I personally close my eyes and concentrate on my breathing taking alternate breaths in and out for a timed a session of 10 minutes. If you feel a burst of creativity, or clear thought after the time is up, then your on the correct path.Ôªø

text:
Hi Jason. Great question! I wanted to recommend you three books I loved: 

1. "Amador" by the spanish philosopher Fernando Savater. He wrote it for his 15 year old son. 

2. "Wide Awake : A Budhist Guide for Teens" by Diana Winston. She is a wonderful meditation teacher. I once watched a lesson on meditation from Yale University on youtube and the professor recommended her guided meditation podcasts. To find them just search for: 
"UCLA Hammer Meditation" on Itunes.

3.  Let me tell you a story by Jorge Bucay. He is a very beloved Argenitinian psychologist. In the book he has this teenaged patient and for every problem he tells during the sessions, Jorge Bucay tells him a very interesting story , related to that problem. That's the kind of book you would finish in one day and  never forget! 
Best wishes :- )Ôªø

text:
Hello there! I understand....Of course we need to motivate ourselves from time to time.  If you wish watch a lesson on the subject from Yale University. To find it just search for this on youtube:
"  Human Emotions II, Mindfulness, Yale University"
The professor there recommends the guided meditation podcasts by Diana Winston. I am using them since 5 years. They are excellent. To find them just search for:
" UCLA Hammer Meditation" on Itunes. 


Doing it with a meditation teacher feels much better and you stop doubting whether you are doing it right or not. Just try the podcast. 

Many greetings and best wishes :- )Ôªø

text:
I'm going to choose meditation as my keystone habit for the rest of the course. It's something I've been working on for the past three weeks, so I want to keep it going. I'm noticing significant changes within my life, including all of the aforementioned in the video. My reason for choosing meditation as my keystone habit is because I know that our thoughts create our reality. When I am in the process of changing my relationship with my thoughts, I change my relationship with reality. I can navigate thoughts with more awareness, clarity and understanding as I journey through meditation. Once I reach automaticity with meditation, my mind will be sharpened and focused which will allow other tasks and habits to be dealt with relative ease. 

Thanks for these videos and I'll be supporting on Patreon!Ôªø
